content.text: On Fig. 1.2, plot these points and draw the best straight line for your points
Find the value of this force
A force smaller than that in (b)(i) is applied to the stationary trolley. Suggest what happens to the trolley, if anything
The graph shows that below a certain force there is no acceleration
Show that the gradient of your graph is about 5.7
gradient =   .........
State the equation that links resultant force \(F,\) mass \(m\) and acceleration \(a.\)
Use your gradient from (c) to find the mass of the trolley
On Fig. 1.3, sketch a speed/time graph for a trolley with constant acceleration
In a laboratory, an experiment is carried out to measure the acceleration of a trolley on a table, when pulled by a horizontal force
The measurements are repeated for a series of different forces, with the results shown in the table below
In the table below, list the three quantities they must measure in order to calculate one man's power, and the instrument they would use for each measurement
One workman is measured as having a power of 528W. His weight is 800N
He can develop the same power climbing a ladder, whose rungs are \(30 \text{cm}\) apart
How many rungs can he climb in 5s?
The human body is only about \(15\%\) efficient when climbing ladders
Calculate the actual energy used from the body of the workman in **(b)** when he climbs
energy used =   .........
Some builders decide to measure their personal power ratings using apparatus they on site. Fig. 2.1 shows the arrangement they use
the force of the air on the surface of the pond,
the pressure at the bottom of the pond
Study the diagram and state, giving your reason, what happens during this hot period to
Water has a density of \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)
Calculate the pressure at the bottom of the pond due to the water
pressure due to the water =   .........
Atmospheric pressure on that day is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{ Pa}\)
Calculate the total pressure at the bottom of the pond
total pressure =   .........
A bubble of gas is released from the mud at the bottom of the pond. Its initial volume is \(0.5 \text{cm}^3\)
Ignoring any temperature differences in the water, calculate the volume of the bubble as it reaches the surface
In fact, the temperature of the water is greater at the top than at the bottom of the pond
Comment on the bubble volume you have calculated in **(b)(iii)**
On a certain day, the pond is \(12 \text{m}\) deep
During a period of hot weather, the atmospheric pressure on the pond in Fig. 3.1 remains
Water evaporates from the pond, so that the depth \(h\) decreases
State the name and purpose of component X
name
Calculate the current in the heater when it has the correct potential difference across it
current =   .........
Calculate the resistance of component X if there is to be the correct potential difference across the heater. The battery and the ammeter both have zero resistance
resistance =   .........
The heater is designed to work from a \(3.6\mathrm{V}\) supply. It has a power rating of \(4.5\mathrm{W}\) at this voltage
Some time after the heater is switched on, the ammeter reading is seen to have decreased
Suggest why this happens
reduce the potential difference from that of the mains supply down to a potential difference suitable for the heater,
change the current from a.c. to a current which has only one direction
As an alternative to running the heater from a battery, it is decided to construct enable it to be operated from the a.c. mains supply
Name the electrical component needed to
The circuit of Fig. 4.1 is set up to run a small immersion heater from a 6.0V battery
60Hz,
1 kW
State what electrical quantity is represented by
Which part of the electric heater must be earthed?
Explain what the hazard might be if the heater is not earthed
The heater has two 110V heating elements, with two switches, so that either one or both elements may be switched on
In the space below, draw a circuit diagram showing how the heating elements and switches are connected to the mains supply
Use the symbol \(\boxed{\begin{array}{r}\end{array}}\boxed{\begin{array}{r}\end{array}}\boxed{\begin{array}{r}\end{array}}\) for each heating element
The manufacturer's label on an electric heater is as shown in Fig. 5.1
Fig. 5.1
Six different nuclides have nucleon and proton numbers as follows:
State which two nuclides are isotopes of the same element. ................... and ................
Calculate the time taken for the activity of this sample to fall to \(15 \text{Bq}\)
time taken   .........
Explain why, when the activity has become \(15 \text{Bq}\), much of the sample will no longer be thorium-232
The sample of thorium-232 is used in an experiment in a laboratory
Explain why its activity may be regarded as constant
Thorium-232 has a half-life of \(1.4 \times 10^{10}\) years
At a particular instant, the activity of a sample of thorium-232 is \(120 \text{Bq}\)
The speed of light in air is known to be \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
Outline how you would use a refraction experiment to deduce the speed of light in glass may draw a diagram if it helps to clarify your answer
Calculate the frequency of the tsunami waves
frequency =   .........
The shock wave from the earthquake travels at \(2.5 \times 10^{3} \text{m} /\text{s}\)
The centre of the earthquake is \(6.0 \times 10^{5} \text{m}\) from the coast of a country
Calculate how much warning of the arrival of the tsunami at the coast is given by the earth tremor felt at the coast
warning time =   .........
A tsunami is a giant water wave. It may be caused by an earthquake below the ocean
Waves from a certain tsunami have a wavelength of \(1.9 \times 10^{5} \text{m}\) and a speed of \(240 \text{m/s}\)
State and explain what happens to the ray already drawn, after it reaches the boundary between the materials
On Fig. 8.1, carefully continue the ray until it reaches the end of the section of optical fibre
Fig. 8.1 shows a section of an optical fibre. It consists of a fibre of denser transpa
coated with a layer of a less dense transparent material
One ray within the fibre has been started for you on Fig. 8.1
Suggest one reason why the cable is made of thousands of very thin optical fibres
Describe briefly how the inside of the stomach is illuminated
Describe briefly how the light from the stomach is transferred to the detecting outside the body
Fibre-optic cables are sometimes used to carry out internal examinations on the human stomach
For this position, state the direction of the force on AB and the direction of the motion of AB
force on AB
Explain why BC does not contribute to the turning force on the coil
At the instant illustrated in Fig. 9.1, the coil ABCD is horizontal and the battery is connected as shown
At the instant when the coil is vertical, the springy contacts do not, in fact, make the ends of the coil
Describe and explain what happens to the coil
The motor in Fig. 9.1 does not rotate very quickly. The designer of a commercial motor is required to produce a faster-rotating motor
Suggest **one** change that could be made to increase the speed of the motor
A simple motor is made in a school laboratory. A coil of wire is mounted on an axle
poles of a horseshoe magnet, as illustrated in Fig. 9.1
A cathode-ray oscilloscope makes use of the process known as thermionic emission
Describe what happens during this process
In the space below, draw a labelled diagram of a cathode-ray oscilloscope
Include in your diagram the tube, the cathode, the accelerating anode, the focusing anode and both X- and Y-plates. Do not attempt to show any external circuits
A cathode ray is a beam of electrons
Suggest one way of controlling the number of electrons in the beam
the current caused by the beam,
current =   .........
the energy transferred by the beam in 20s
One cathode-ray tube has \(5000\mathrm{V}\) between the accelerating anode and the cathode
The beam of electrons carries a total charge of \(0.0095 \text{C}\) in \(5.0 \text{s}\)
Calculate
Calculate the specific latent heat of the substance
specific latent heat =   .........
After 11 minutes of heating, when the temperature starts rising again, in which state is the substance?
Describe what happens to the molecules as thermal energy is supplied to them in this state
A mass of \(0.36\mathrm{kg}\) of a certain substance is in the solid state in a well-insulated container substance is heated at the rate of \(1.2 \times 10^{4}\mathrm{J / minute}\)
2.0 minutes after starting the heating, the substance is all at the same temperature, and it starts to melt
11.0 minutes after starting the heating, the substance finishes melting and the temperature starts to rise again
